Best Directory Brute-forcing Tools for Beginner Bug Hunters
Hello hackers and bug hunters,
I am Josekutty a cybersecurity researcher and ethical hacker. I am here to introduce you some of the best directory brute-forcing tools I use in my day-to-day bug hunting process. Over the time using these tools I’ve had the privilege to secure top organisations like Siemens, NASA, Audi, Panasonic and lot more.
FIRST THINGS FIRST, WHAT IS ACTUALLY DIRECTORY BRUTE-FORCING ?
Directory brute-forcing is a technique searching for hidden directories and files on websites which can sometimes revel vulnerabilities and sensitive information.
I will introduce four best directory brute-forcing tools I use personally in my bug hunting journey.
Dirb
Dirb is one of the first tools I used when I started out in bug hunting. It’s a straightforward and powerful tool designed to find hidden directories and files on websites.

Installation:

sudo apt-get install dirb

Basic usage:

dirb https://target.com

Github link: 'https://github.com/v0re/dirb?source=post_page-----3388dd97c055---------------------------------------'
Gobuster

Gobuster is another tool I frequently use. It’s fast and efficient, making it ideal for scanning large wordlists quickly.

Installation:

sudo apt install gobuster

Basic usage:

gobuster dir -u http://target.com -w /(path to the wordlist using)

Github link:'https://github.com/OJ/gobuster?source=post_page-----3388dd97c055---------------------------------------'
Dirsearch

Dirsearch is a Python-based tool.

Installation:

git clone https://github.com/maurosoria/dirsearch.git

cd dirsearch

pip install -r requirements

Basic usage:

python3 dirsearch -u https://target.com

Github link:'https://github.com/maurosoria/dirsearch?source=post_page-----3388dd97c055---------------------------------------'
ffuf (Fuzz Faster U Fool)

Ffuf is one of the most flexible tools in my arsenal. It’s fast and can be used for directory brute-forcing as well as parameter fuzzing, making it a versatile choice for various scenarios.

Installation:

sudo apt install ffuf

Basic usage:

ffuf -u https://target.com/FUZZ -w /(path to the wordlist using)

Github link:'https://github.com/ffuf/ffuf?source=post_page-----3388dd97c055---------------------------------------'
Another key point, when using the default wordlists for directory brute-forcing if you are not getting any result try to use wordlists according to the components used in the backend of the website. Analyse using Wappalyzer extension. Or another method is to create a wordlist using crunch or cewl tools, these tools are used to create wordlists according to the website you want to enumerate.
Happy Hacking
